required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Improving Diabetes Care Collaboratively in the Community
clinical_study.official_title: Improving Diabetes Care Collaboratively in the Community

collaborator.agency: Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ)

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to determine whether a quality improvement intervention including rapid quality improvement, a chronic care model, and best practices improves diabetes care in community health centers and whether more intensive interventions enhance care further.

detailed_description.textblock: In 1998 the Health Resources and Services Administration's Bureau of Primary Health Care began the Health Disparities Collaborative (HDC) to improve chronic disease management in community health centers (HC) nationwide. The HDC incorporates rapid quality improvement (QI), a chronic care model, and best practices. This study determines if the HDC improves diabetes care and whether more intensive interventions with additional learning sessions for health centers, provider training in behavioral change, and patient empowerment materials enhance care further.

primary_outcome.description: Change in hemoglobin A1c from baseline

secondary_outcome.description: Change in Lipid blood levels from baseline
Change in urine micralbumin levels from baseline

arm_group.description: The HDC incorporates rapid quality improvement (QI), a chronic care model, and best practices. This study determines if the HDC improves diabetes care and whether more intensive interventions with additional learning sessions for health centers, provider training in behavioral change, and patient empowerment materials enhance care further.
No additional educational sessions added to usual care of patients.

intervention.description: The HDC incorporates rapid quality improvement (QI), a chronic care model, and best practices. This study determines if the HDC improves diabetes care and whether more intensive interventions with additional learning sessions for health centers, provider training in behavioral change, and patient empowerment materials enhance care further.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- patients with diabetes age 18-75 years
Exclusion Criteria:
Pregnant women

results_reference.citation: Chin MH, Drum ML, Guillen M, Rimington A, Levie JR, Kirchhoff AC, Quinn MT, Schaefer CT. Improving and sustaining diabetes care in community health centers with the health disparities collaboratives. Med Care. 2007 Dec;45(12):1135-43.
